slides.title: Welcome to Activities
slides.notes: Introduction to activities in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our session on Activities within Guidewire PolicyCenter. Activities are essential in managing tasks and alerts for various processes. They play a crucial role in policy and transaction management by ensuring users are notified and tasks are completed efficiently. Let's dive into how activities are structured and utilized in PolicyCenter.

slides.notes: Activities are linked to accounts, transactions, and policies.
slides.narration: Activities are versatile tools in PolicyCenter, linked to accounts, transactions, and policies. Whether you're managing a policy job or dealing with transactions, activities ensure that nothing slips through the cracks.

slides.title: Activities Overview
slides.originalNotes:
Activities
An activity represents a task or issue that must be addressed. Activities are associated with accounts, transactions, or a policy. Both transactions andpolices are associated with accounts. Activities can:
Let processes and users assign work to users
Alert users to certain events
Manage how policy jobs are completed

slides.title: Activity Patterns
slides.originalNotes:
Activity patterns
An activity pattern is a template that standardizes the way PolicyCenter creates activities. The activity pattern specifies details about an activity, whichinclude: subject, priority, number of days until due, etc. Activities follow the specified activity pattern. Managers have the ability to create and modify activity patterns on the PolicyCenter Administration tab user interface.

Configuration users can organize the data model to add fields to the activity pattern entity. When a field is added to the activity pattern entity, it is available on all activity patterns. For example, a carrier might want to add a "Required Role" field used to identify the role a person must have in order to have this type of activity assigned.

slides.title: Activity Ownership
slides.originalNotes:
Activity ownership: explicit and implicit
An activity can be assigned to a user explicitly or implicitly. When an activity is explicitly assigned to a user, that user is either chosen by the user creating the activity or by the routing rules. Changes to any job or account will not affect the ownership of the activity.

When an activity is implicitly assigned to a user, it is actually assigned to a specific role on a job or account (i.e., the underwriter for Big Lake Bakery).  The activity is "owned" by the user who has that role (in the example, Alice Applegate). If that role is later reassigned to another user, then all activities assigned via roles will be reassigned to that user. In the slide example, if the undewriter role for Big Lake Bakery is later reassigned to Bob Baker, then the second activity will also be reassigned to Bob Baker. Alice owned the second activity be virtue of being the underwriter for the Big Lake Bakery account.

slides.narration: Activities can be owned explicitly by a designated user or implicitly through roles. Implicit assignment is dynamic, adapting to role changes. This flexibility ensures that the right person always handles the task, even if team roles evolve.

slides.title: Activity Queues
slides.originalNotes:
Activity queues
A queue is an activity repository and is associated with the group. Users in a group can take ownership of queued activities.  From the Desktop, navigate to My Queue. To self-assign an activity, click Assign Next to Me. The user must have the Get next activity from queue (actquenext)  permission to assign an activity from the queue. In the base configuration, the underwriter role has this permission.
slides.notes:
Activity queues
A queue is an activity repository and is associated with the group. Users in a group can take ownership of queued activities.  From the Desktop, navigate to My Queue. To self-assign an activity, click Assign Next to Me. The user must have the Get next activity from queue (actquenext)  permission to assign an activity from the queue. In the base configuration, the underwriter role has this permission.
slides.narration: Activity queues act as repositories, linked to groups where users can claim tasks. This setup promotes shared responsibility and balanced workload distribution, essential for team efficiency.
